THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, No. 27.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MICHIGAN WINS CONTEST

PHI BETA KAPPA ELECTIONS

VARSITY DEFEATS LEHIGH

HOPKINS, 44; NAVY, 57

The First Prize Awarded to Representative of Albion College Illinois Wesleyan Second.

Only Four Seniors Receive the Coveted
Honor This Year—Twenty-nine
New Members.

An Intensely Exciting Game Is Pulled
Out of the Fire at the
Last Minute.

Horrax and Lee Star for Track and
Field Team—Records Broken
at Annapolis.

Amid the beautiful decorations of
McCoy Hall, hung, as it was, with
the flags of all nations, and the
banners of universal peace, the
Fifth Inter-State Oratorical Contest
of the Inter-collegiate Peace Association was held last Friday night.
Seven States were represented by
the winners of their own championship contests; and the two prizes,
one of $75, the other of $50, were
awarded to Mr. Stanley H. Howe,
of Beloit College, Michigan, and
to Mr. Wayne Calhoun, of Illinois
Wesleyan University, respectively,
by a committee of judges, consisting of Judge Stockbridge, of the
Maryland Court of Appeal; judge
Bond, of Westminster: Dr. Fell,
president of St. John's College;
Prof. Hodell, of Goucher College;
and Mr. A. H. Snow, of Washington, D. C.
The exercises opened with a
piano solo by Mr. P. C. Kuehn,'Ir.
Then followed a few introductory
remarks by the presiding officer,
Dean William P. Rodgers, of the
Cincinnati Law School, president of
the Intercollegiate Peace Association; and then the order of speaking.
The first sneaker was Mr. James
Quinlin, of Notre Dame University,
Indiana. who spoke on "America
and Universal Peace." He was followed by our own Mr. Bobbitt,
whose polished and dignified performance was no whit inferior to
what we ,expected of him,but which
seemed strangely out of place amid
the rampant oratory of the Western
school which reigned supreme on
the occasion.
The third speaker was the winner
of the contest, Mr. Howe, of Michigan. His voice was loud, his style
was rugged; but his theme struck
a sympathetic chord in the hearts
of the audience; and he was interrupted by successive bursts of applause as he proclaimed that the
hope of peace could be achieved
only by instillincr peaceful sentimenth into the minds of the rising
generation.
Mr. T-Towe was succeeded by a
speaker who was his antithesis in
every respect, Mr. Lawrence W.
Bridge, of Hiram College, Ohio,
whose mellow voice and glib erudition were expressed on tracing the
"Evolution of World Peace."
After the first four orators had
done, there followed an intermission. during which Mr. Uhlig refreshed the audience with two solos.

The regular annual meeting for
the election of officers and members of the Alpha Chapter of the
honorary fraternity, Phi Beta
Kappa, was held in the Donovan
Room, McCoy Hall, on Wednesday, May 3, at 4 o'clock. The following officers for the ensuing year
were elected: President, Dr. L.
F. Barker; vice-president, Dr. W.
B. Clark; secretary, Dr. L. M.
Raney; treasurer, Dr. L. S. Hulbert.
The following undergraduates,
having the necessary average, were
elected members: L. B. Bobbitt,
F. C. Kuehn, J. B. Reeside. Jr.,
and Leo Wolman; of the medical
men, the following were elected:
T. A. C. Colston, D. M Davis, E.
G. Grey, U. N. Leonard, H. Lisser, J. T. MacCurdy, W. G. Sexton, Miss H. W. Smith, and Miss
S. M. Wolfsohn.
Of the graduate students in philosophy, the following were elected
in the order: Messrs. T. B. Ashcroft, W. S. Fox, Griinbaum, J. S.
Gay, E. L. Highbarger, N. E.
Loomis, J. L, McShea, F. A. MaGruder, S. B. Mertie, Jr., F. E.
Wolfe, H. H. York, and' P.'G.
Agnew.
Five members of the faculty were
also elected to membership. They
are: Dr. J. C. Bloodgood, Dr. S.
M.T.Finney, Dr. W. W. Holland,
Dr. H. A. Kelly, and Dr. L. A.
Terracher.
The banquet which always follows the election was held Saturday evening, at 7 o'clock, in the
Donovan Room. The speaker of
the evening was Mr. Paul Shorey.
There was an unusually small
number of undergraduates elected
this year. Only two of the four
men who received the honor were
seniors. The other two were
juniors, Mr. Wolman and Mr.
Kuehn both being members of the
1912 class who have gone through
the University in three years. To
be thus elected is particularly an
honor. Several seniors, unfortunately, fell just shortof the requisite
average for admission.
These
men, however, can console themselves with the thought that Hopkins is the *hardest University in
the country to enter the Phi Beta
Kappa through.

. The University • lacrosse team
again on Saturday afternoon, at
Homewood, showed its unquestioned mastery of the Indian game, and
ability to play against heavy odds,
when they won from Lehigh by a
score of 6 to.4. This-simple statement, however, does not tell the
,story of the game, as it was one of
the hardest contests ever seen in
Baltimore, and for a time it looked
as .if the Varsity was going to suffer its first defeat of the season.
It was only after Hopkins had
made a splendid rally in the -first
half, scoring -three goals in less
than that number of minutes, thus
tying the score; and after the
coaches made material changes in
the system of play and lineup, infusing new blood into the game as
the. second session progressed, that
the victory was 'really certain, and
then in the last few Minutes of the
second stanza, Lehigh made a'good
spurt and, for a time was very
dangerous.
The South I3ethlehemites showed
unexpected strength and made more
attempts at our goal than did the
Varsity at theirs.. The successful
result can undoubtedly be attributed
to Sutton, who was a veritable
wonder between the posts, stopping
no less than twenty-five shots, many
of which 'were very 'difficult ones.
Of course so far as winning the
contest goes, we put the praise on
the shoulders of one of the best
attack men the game had ever produced, and take our hats off to him
now, as we. did after the Swarthmore contest, for his two goals on
Saturday enabled Hopkins to win.

On Saturday afternoon, the Hopkins Track and Field Team met the
team of the Naval Academy at Annapolis.
Horrax and Lee were the stars
of the contest. Horrax contributed
twenty points to Hopkins' score by
winning, the 120-yards hurdles, the
broad jump, the high jump; and the
pole vault; His time in the hurdles
was only two-fifths of a .§econd
behind the inter-collegiate record,
and almost a second better than the
Navy record. Lee won both the
mile and the two Mile runs in record time, breaking the I-Iokpins and
the Navy marks in the one-mile and
the Hopkins record in the two-mile.
missing the Navy record by onefifth of a. second. His two-mile
race was the greatest event of the
day, for after doing the mile in 4
minutes 30Y5 seconds, he won handily by some thirty yards from fresh
men.

the evening of June 12. The price
will be $3.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1911.

COLLEGE TRADITIONS.

College traditions—that is a term
which is almost unknown here at
Hopkins. A crowded city with its
gloomy buildings and nerve-racking noises provides a poor soil for
the planting of the seeds of tradition. A few customs, to be sure,
did spring up; but they were never
firmly rooted and most of them have
withered away and died. The
change from the three-year to a
four-year course appears to have
been the principal cause of this. At
least the decadence of our customs
seems to date from the arrival of
the first four-year class at the University. The class-rush is almost
gone. The cane-rush no longer
arouses the interest it used to do.
And the games in the Baltimore Lacrosse League are a poor substitute
for the former inter-class lacrosse
games. The Hullabaloo, alas! has
not seen the light of day since 1909.
But, of course, however much
we may will to have traditions, it
avails us naught. A tradition is a
plant which grows spontaneously.
Like pleasure, the more we pursue
it, the less likely are we to attain
it. We go on in our daily round
of activities and some day we wake
up to find that we have traditions.
But it is a slow process.
On the other hand, certain customs can be inaugurated at will.
For instance, most colleges have a
class day towards the end of the
year, which is a day of general jollification. Exercises are held, a
program is rendered, and the seniors appear in all their glory, with
caps and gowns. No doubt everyone will think that a cap and gown
would look strangely out of place
on Garden street. But not so.

The form of THE NEWS-LETTER
has evidently appealed to others besides ourselves. The elementary
teachers of Baltimore have begun
the publication of a monthly leaflet,
which in form, size of type, and
headlines, is an exact reproduction
of our paper.

The first of the speakers after
the intermission was Mr. Wayne
Calhoun, of Illinois, who was
awarded second prize. His subject was "War and the Man," and
he painted more than one graphic
and harrowing picture of the desolation and woe which war produces. Mr. Calhoun was followed
by Mr. C. L. Saxby, of Beloit College, Wisconsin, who delivered an
exceedingly dramatic, almost histrionic oration on the "Evolution of
Peace."
The last speaker, Mr. C. M.
Lodge, of Dickinson, was, in the
opinion of many of the audience,
one of the very best who spoke.
His oration on the "Proposed Court
of Arbitral Justice" was rendered
with a delivery which was all that
polished taste and scholarly judgment could demand; and the structu_ e of his oration, the pith of his
matter, was only inferior to that
exhibited in the speech of Mr. Bobbitt.
The decision of the judges came
as a surprise to many. In announcing the awards, Dean Rodgers took
occasion to bestow high praise upon
all the orations delivered; but in the
opinion of more than one, altogether too many prophets spoke,
too many meteors flashed, too many
Nazarenes died, and too many
fawns came out of the East in some
of the speeches which did not receive the lowest mark.

THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, No. 27.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MICHIGAN WINS CONTEST

PHI BETA KAPPA ELECTIONS

VARSITY DEFEATS LEHIGH

HOPKINS, 44; NAVY, 57

The First Prize Awarded to Representative of Albion College Illinois Wesleyan Second.

Only Four Seniors Receive the Coveted
Honor This Year—Twenty-nine
New Members.

An Intensely Exciting Game Is Pulled
Out of the Fire at the
Last Minute.

Horrax and Lee Star for Track and
Field Team—Records Broken
at Annapolis.

Amid the beautiful decorations of
McCoy Hall, hung, as it was, with
the flags of all nations, and the
banners of universal peace, the
Fifth Inter-State Oratorical Contest
of the Inter-collegiate Peace Association was held last Friday night.
Seven States were represented by
the winners of their own championship contests; and the two prizes,
one of $75, the other of $50, were
awarded to Mr. Stanley H. Howe,
of Beloit College, Michigan, and
to Mr. Wayne Calhoun, of Illinois
Wesleyan University, respectively,
by a committee of judges, consisting of Judge Stockbridge, of the
Maryland Court of Appeal; judge
Bond, of Westminster: Dr. Fell,
president of St. John's College;
Prof. Hodell, of Goucher College;
and Mr. A. H. Snow, of Washington, D. C.
The exercises opened with a
piano solo by Mr. P. C. Kuehn,'Ir.
Then followed a few introductory
remarks by the presiding officer,
Dean William P. Rodgers, of the
Cincinnati Law School, president of
the Intercollegiate Peace Association; and then the order of speaking.
The first sneaker was Mr. James
Quinlin, of Notre Dame University,
Indiana. who spoke on "America
and Universal Peace." He was followed by our own Mr. Bobbitt,
whose polished and dignified performance was no whit inferior to
what we ,expected of him,but which
seemed strangely out of place amid
the rampant oratory of the Western
school which reigned supreme on
the occasion.
The third speaker was the winner
of the contest, Mr. Howe, of Michigan. His voice was loud, his style
was rugged; but his theme struck
a sympathetic chord in the hearts
of the audience; and he was interrupted by successive bursts of applause as he proclaimed that the
hope of peace could be achieved
only by instillincr peaceful sentimenth into the minds of the rising
generation.
Mr. T-Towe was succeeded by a
speaker who was his antithesis in
every respect, Mr. Lawrence W.
Bridge, of Hiram College, Ohio,
whose mellow voice and glib erudition were expressed on tracing the
"Evolution of World Peace."
After the first four orators had
done, there followed an intermission. during which Mr. Uhlig refreshed the audience with two solos.

The regular annual meeting for
the election of officers and members of the Alpha Chapter of the
honorary fraternity, Phi Beta
Kappa, was held in the Donovan
Room, McCoy Hall, on Wednesday, May 3, at 4 o'clock. The following officers for the ensuing year
were elected: President, Dr. L.
F. Barker; vice-president, Dr. W.
B. Clark; secretary, Dr. L. M.
Raney; treasurer, Dr. L. S. Hulbert.
The following undergraduates,
having the necessary average, were
elected members: L. B. Bobbitt,
F. C. Kuehn, J. B. Reeside. Jr.,
and Leo Wolman; of the medical
men, the following were elected:
T. A. C. Colston, D. M Davis, E.
G. Grey, U. N. Leonard, H. Lisser, J. T. MacCurdy, W. G. Sexton, Miss H. W. Smith, and Miss
S. M. Wolfsohn.
Of the graduate students in philosophy, the following were elected
in the order: Messrs. T. B. Ashcroft, W. S. Fox, Griinbaum, J. S.
Gay, E. L. Highbarger, N. E.
Loomis, J. L, McShea, F. A. MaGruder, S. B. Mertie, Jr., F. E.
Wolfe, H. H. York, and' P.'G.
Agnew.
Five members of the faculty were
also elected to membership. They
are: Dr. J. C. Bloodgood, Dr. S.
M.T.Finney, Dr. W. W. Holland,
Dr. H. A. Kelly, and Dr. L. A.
Terracher.
The banquet which always follows the election was held Saturday evening, at 7 o'clock, in the
Donovan Room. The speaker of
the evening was Mr. Paul Shorey.
There was an unusually small
number of undergraduates elected
this year. Only two of the four
men who received the honor were
seniors. The other two were
juniors, Mr. Wolman and Mr.
Kuehn both being members of the
1912 class who have gone through
the University in three years. To
be thus elected is particularly an
honor. Several seniors, unfortunately, fell just shortof the requisite
average for admission.
These
men, however, can console themselves with the thought that Hopkins is the *hardest University in
the country to enter the Phi Beta
Kappa through.

. The University • lacrosse team
again on Saturday afternoon, at
Homewood, showed its unquestioned mastery of the Indian game, and
ability to play against heavy odds,
when they won from Lehigh by a
score of 6 to.4. This-simple statement, however, does not tell the
,story of the game, as it was one of
the hardest contests ever seen in
Baltimore, and for a time it looked
as .if the Varsity was going to suffer its first defeat of the season.
It was only after Hopkins had
made a splendid rally in the -first
half, scoring -three goals in less
than that number of minutes, thus
tying the score; and after the
coaches made material changes in
the system of play and lineup, infusing new blood into the game as
the. second session progressed, that
the victory was 'really certain, and
then in the last few Minutes of the
second stanza, Lehigh made a'good
spurt and, for a time was very
dangerous.
The South I3ethlehemites showed
unexpected strength and made more
attempts at our goal than did the
Varsity at theirs.. The successful
result can undoubtedly be attributed
to Sutton, who was a veritable
wonder between the posts, stopping
no less than twenty-five shots, many
of which 'were very 'difficult ones.
Of course so far as winning the
contest goes, we put the praise on
the shoulders of one of the best
attack men the game had ever produced, and take our hats off to him
now, as we. did after the Swarthmore contest, for his two goals on
Saturday enabled Hopkins to win.

On Saturday afternoon, the Hopkins Track and Field Team met the
team of the Naval Academy at Annapolis.
Horrax and Lee were the stars
of the contest. Horrax contributed
twenty points to Hopkins' score by
winning, the 120-yards hurdles, the
broad jump, the high jump; and the
pole vault; His time in the hurdles
was only two-fifths of a .§econd
behind the inter-collegiate record,
and almost a second better than the
Navy record. Lee won both the
mile and the two Mile runs in record time, breaking the I-Iokpins and
the Navy marks in the one-mile and
the Hopkins record in the two-mile.
missing the Navy record by onefifth of a. second. His two-mile
race was the greatest event of the
day, for after doing the mile in 4
minutes 30Y5 seconds, he won handily by some thirty yards from fresh
men.

the evening of June 12. The price
will be $3.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1911.

COLLEGE TRADITIONS.

College traditions—that is a term
which is almost unknown here at
Hopkins. A crowded city with its
gloomy buildings and nerve-racking noises provides a poor soil for
the planting of the seeds of tradition. A few customs, to be sure,
did spring up; but they were never
firmly rooted and most of them have
withered away and died. The
change from the three-year to a
four-year course appears to have
been the principal cause of this. At
least the decadence of our customs
seems to date from the arrival of
the first four-year class at the University. The class-rush is almost
gone. The cane-rush no longer
arouses the interest it used to do.
And the games in the Baltimore Lacrosse League are a poor substitute
for the former inter-class lacrosse
games. The Hullabaloo, alas! has
not seen the light of day since 1909.
But, of course, however much
we may will to have traditions, it
avails us naught. A tradition is a
plant which grows spontaneously.
Like pleasure, the more we pursue
it, the less likely are we to attain
it. We go on in our daily round
of activities and some day we wake
up to find that we have traditions.
But it is a slow process.
On the other hand, certain customs can be inaugurated at will.
For instance, most colleges have a
class day towards the end of the
year, which is a day of general jollification. Exercises are held, a
program is rendered, and the seniors appear in all their glory, with
caps and gowns. No doubt everyone will think that a cap and gown
would look strangely out of place
on Garden street. But not so.

The form of THE NEWS-LETTER
has evidently appealed to others besides ourselves. The elementary
teachers of Baltimore have begun
the publication of a monthly leaflet,
which in form, size of type, and
headlines, is an exact reproduction
of our paper.

he painted more than one graphic
and harrowing picture of the desolation and woe which war produces. Mr. Calhoun was followed
by Mr. C. L. Saxby, of Beloit College, Wisconsin, who delivered an
exceedingly dramatic, almost histrionic oration on the "Evolution of
Peace."
The last speaker, Mr. C. M.
Lodge, of Dickinson, was, in the
opinion of many of the audience,
one of the very best who spoke.
His oration on the "Proposed Court
of Arbitral Justice" was rendered
with a delivery which was all that
polished taste and scholarly judgment could demand; and the structu_ e of his oration, the pith of his
matter, was only inferior to that
exhibited in the speech of Mr. Bobbitt.
The decision of the judges came
as a surprise to many. In announcing the awards, Dean Rodgers took
occasion to bestow high praise upon
all the orations delivered; but in the
opinion of more than one, altogether too many prophets spoke,
too many meteors flashed, too many
Nazarenes died, and too many
fawns came out of the East in some
of the speeches which did not receive the lowest mark.
